name: ghost
content:
ghost noun
(SPIRIT)
Add to word list
Add to word list
B1 [ C ] the spirit of a dead person, sometimes represented as a pale, almost transparent image of that person that some people believe appears to people who are alive: believe in ghosts Do you believe in ghosts?haunted by a ghost The gardens are said to be haunted by the ghost of a child who drowned in the river.
More examplesFewer examplesA headless ghost walks the castle at night - or so the story goes.According to tradition, a headless ghost walks through the corridors of the house at night.The Society for Psychical Research is investigating reports of a ghost at the old vicarage.Have you ever seen a ghost?There's no such thing as ghosts.

ghost verb
(WRITE)
[ T ] (also ghostwrite) to write a book, article, etc. for another person to publish under their own name: A writer friend of his was ghosting the autobiography of a jockey. Most of Reagan's newspaper columns were ghosted for him.
More examplesFewer examplesAround 80 percent of celebrity books are ghosted.Tony is ghosting the memoirs of Eddie, an ex-con who went to prison for his part in a bullion robbery. He is a freelance writer who is ghosting an article for a corporate executive.

ghost verb
(END COMMUNICATION)
[ I or T ] informal to end a relationship with someone suddenly by stopping all communication with them: Should I message her back or just ghost? I couldn't understand why I'd been ghosted.
More examplesFewer examplesShe was furious about being ghosted by Dan.If you want to finish with a boyfriend, tell him, don't just ghost.He ghosted his girlfriend and then she became his boss.
